item.title: NBGC
item.description:
Axioms of NBGC (the Usual Axioms for Algebraists)

Throughout, $A$ and $B$ are classes and $C$ and $D$ are sets.

  1. (å¤–å»¶å…¬ç†: Axiom of extensionality). CLASSES are equal if and only if they have the same MEMBERS. For all $c âˆˆ A$, if and only if $c âˆˆ B$ then $A=B$.
    • In ZF, (CLASSES, MEMBERS) are replaced by (sets, elements).
  2. (æ­£å‰‡å…¬ç†: Axiom of Regularity). All non-empty CLASSES are disjoint from at least one of their MEMBERS.
    • In ZF, (CLASSES, MEMBERS) are replaced by (sets, elements).
  3. (åˆ†é›¢å…¬ç†æ¨¡å¼: Axiom (Schema) of Class Comprehension/Separation/Specification, it is an axiom schema because there is one axiom for each $Ï•$) For any formula $Ï•$ which does not quantify over CLASS, there is a CLASS $A$ such that $x âˆˆ A$ if and only if $Ï•(x)$ is true, i.e, $$\begin{equation} âˆ€ zâˆ€ w_{1}âˆ€ w_{2}\ldots âˆ€ w_{n}âˆƒ yâˆ€ x[xâˆˆ y â‡” ((x âˆˆ z)âˆ§ Ï† (x,w_{1},w_{2},\ldots,w_{n},z))], \end{equation}$$ where $(z,w_1,w_2,\ldots, w_n,x)$ are free variables ($y$ is not free).
    • Axiom of Empty Set is a corollary.
    • In ZF, CLASSES is replaced by sets.
  4. (é…å°å…¬ç†: Axiom of Pairing). For any two sets $C$ and $D$, there is a set with exactly $C$ and $D$ as elements.
    • It is exactly the same as the Axiom of Pairing in ZF.
  5. (ä½µé›†å…¬ç†: Axiom of Union). you can take the union of any set of sets.
    • It is exactly the same as the Axiom of Union in ZF.
  6. (æ›¿æ›å…¬ç†æ¨¡å¼: Axiom (Schema). of Replacement/Collection/Size, also 6 names) For any CLASS $A$, there is a set $c$ such that $c=\mathrm{Rep}(A)$ if and only if there is no total one-to-one function between $A$ and the CLASS of all sets. This is the one that creates that definition of classes as things too big to be sets.
    • This theorem has a weakened form, which is a the same as that in ZF. Under this stronger form, one can prove that the sub-class of a set is also a set.
  7. (ç„¡çª®å…¬ç†: Axiom of Infinity). There exists a set $N$ where:
    1. The empty set $âˆ…$ is an element of $N$
    2. and for each element $x âˆˆ N$, $x âˆª \{x\} âˆˆ N$;
    • It is exactly the same as the Axiom of Infinity in ZF.
  8. (å†ªé›†å…¬ç†: Axiom of Powerset). For any set $x$, there is a set which contains all of the subsets of $x$.
    • It is exactly the same as the Axiom of Powerset in ZF.

When non-set-theoretic mathematicians talk about NBG, AC for Sets or even Axiom of Global Choice is possibly included.

(20points).

  1. (10 points). Assume that $p$ is a prime number greater than 2. Prove that the polynomial

    $$ f (x) = x^{p-1} + x^{p-2} + \cdots + x + 1 $$

    is irreducible in the rational number field $â„š$.

  2. (10 points). For an integer coefficient polynomial

    $$ f (x) = x^{n} + a_1 x^{n-1} + \cdots + a_{n-1} x + a_{n}, $$

    the sufficient and necessary condition for $f (x)$ to have (non-zero) integer roots is that there are $2(n-1)$ integers $\{ b_i, c_i , \ i = 1, \ldots, n-1\}$ such that

    1. $a_i = b_i + c_i$, for $i = 1, \cdots, n-1$; and
    2. $\frac{1}{c_1} = \frac{b_1}{c_2} = \frac{b_2}{c_3} = \cdots = \frac{b_{n-2}}{c_{n-1}} = \frac{b_{n-1}}{a_{n}}$.

item.title: 2025-04-21 è¯•å·
item.description:
è¯•å·

(20points).

  1. (10 points). Assume that $p$ is a prime number greater than 2. Prove that the polynomial

    $$ f (x) = x^{p-1} + x^{p-2} + \cdots + x + 1 $$

    is irreducible in the rational number field $â„š$.

  2. (10 points). For an integer coefficient polynomial

    $$ f (x) = x^{n} + a_1 x^{n-1} + \cdots + a_{n-1} x + a_{n}, $$

    the sufficient and necessary condition for $f (x)$ to have (non-zero) integer roots is that there are $2(n-1)$ integers $\{ b_i, c_i , \ i = 1, \ldots, n-1\}$ such that

    1. $a_i = b_i + c_i$, for $i = 1, \cdots, n-1$; and
    2. $\frac{1}{c_1} = \frac{b_1}{c_2} = \frac{b_2}{c_3} = \cdots = \frac{b_{n-2}}{c_{n-1}} = \frac{b_{n-1}}{a_{n}}$.

(20 points).

  1. (10 points). Assume that $a,b âˆˆ â„‚$ are two complex numbers. Prove the following two subspaces of $â„‚[x]$,

    $$ \begin{aligned} & V_a=\{f(x) \in \mathbb{C}[x] \mid f(a)=0\}, \\[6pt] & V_b=\{g(x) \in \mathbb{C}[x] \mid g(b)=0\} , \end{aligned} $$

    are isomorphic.

  2. (10 points). Assume that $Îµ_1, Îµ_2, Îµ_3$ is a basis of the linear space $V$, and $f_1, f_2, f_3$ is the dual basis of $Îµ_1, Îµ_2, Îµ_3$. Let

    $$ Î±_1=Îµ_1+Îµ_2+Îµ_3,\quad {Î±}_2=Îµ_2+Îµ_3,\quad {Î±}_3=Îµ_3. $$

    1. Prove that $Î±_1, Î±_2, Î±_3$ is a basis of $V$;
    2. Find the dual basis of $Î±_1, Î±_2, Î±_3$ (using $f_1, f_2, f_3$ to represent).

(20 points). Suppose $V$ is an $n$-dimensional vector space over a number field, and let $V_1, V_2, \ldots, V_s$ be $s$ proper subspaces of $V$. Prove that

  1. There exists some $Î± âˆˆ V$ such that $Î± âˆ‰ V_1 âˆª V_2 âˆª \cdots âˆª V_s$;

  2. There exists a basis of $V, Îµ _1, Îµ _2, \ldots, Îµ _n$, such that

    $$ \left\{Îµ _1, Îµ _2, \ldots, Îµ _n\right\} â‹‚ \left(V_1 âˆª V_2 âˆª \cdots âˆª V_s\right)=âˆ…. $$

(15 points). Suppose $Ï† _1, Ï† _2, \ldots, Ï†_m$ are linear maps over the $n$-dimensional vector space $V$, such that

$$ Ï† _i^2 = Ï† _i\quad \text{and}\quad Ï† _i Ï† _j = 0 \quad (i â‰  j, \ 1 â‰¤ i, \ j â‰¤ m). $$

Prove that

$$ V=\operatorname{im} \varphi_1 âŠ• \operatorname{im} \varphi_2 âŠ• \cdots âŠ• \operatorname{im} Ï†_m âŠ• \bigcap_{i=1}^m \operatorname{ker} Ï†_i . $$

(15 points). Suppose the linear map $ğ’œ (X)=AXA^T$ over $â„^{n Ã— n}$, where $A$ is an $n$-order real square matrix with $\operatorname{rank}(A) = r$. Find the dimension and a basis of $\operatorname{im} ğ’œ$.

(10 points). You are encouraged to have a great amount of reading and thinking besides the classes. This problem is meant to test the your understanding. Please give a new theorem/question that has neither appeared in classes nor in our textbook, and then give a proof/solution to this theorem/question. It can be a phenomenon you have summarized, a theorem in other books, or a theorem that is beyond what we have learned.

Abstract

This is a html-based $\LaTeX$ template for writing articles. This website is based on this outstanding repository, to whose author(s) we extend our sincere gratitude.
